Award.AwardTitle: Reaction Dynamics of Vibrationally Excited Molecules in Gases and Liquids
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a unified study of reactions in liquids and gases with the goal of comparing the influence of vibrational excitation on bimolecular reactions in the two settings and of understanding the role played by the surroundings. In gases, bimolecular reactions can be promoted and controlled using laser pulses to generate a reactive radical, to excite a reactant vibrationally, and to detect the reaction products. The same conceptual approach, using different technology, will be applied in liquids. Gas-phase studies rely on relatively high spectral resolution lasers to prepare and probe individual quantum states of the reactants and products. Because of the frequent encounters in liquids, studies in solution need short time resolution, with the consequence that the spectral resolution of the laser pulses is poorer. Nonetheless, it is possible to excite and probe individual vibrations in liquids by a judicious choice of time and spectral resolution in the excitation and interrogation steps.
This project will use bromine in vibrational-mode selective single collision reactions and compare gas-phase reactions with those in solution. The high time resolution in the solution-phase experiments will allow the direct observation of the evolution of a photolytically generated bromine atom as it forms complexes and reacts with vibrationally excited solvent molecules. Single collision studies of the same reactions in a molecular beam will provide a point of comparison by observing the influence of vibrational excitation without the complication of the surrounding solvent.
The fundamental science in this project will provide valuable experience and skills to graduate students, as well as opportunities designed to integrate research, teaching, and learning at the University of Wisconsin/Madison. The principal investigator will participate in education and policy related activities, and reach out to beginning scientists about the research enterprise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this National Science Foundation supported project is to understand the role of different types of energy in reactions and to test theoretical descriptions of chemical reactions. The consequences of such understanding touch on processes ranging from the immediately practical, such as combustion, to the fundamental and long range, such as theoretical descriptions of chemistry and insight into reactions in exotic environments.

Chemical reactions occur only when the potentially reactive molecules contain enough energy to overcome the inherent barriers to breaking and making chemical bonds. The most common example is heating food to accelerate the chemical reactions that occur in cooking. However, the details are more subtle, and a major theme in chemical research is identifying the effects of different forms of energy. It is even possible to use that understanding to control the course of a chemical reaction.

Two forms of energy that play a big role are translational energy, the energy of relative motion of the molecules, and vibrational energy, the energy of the motion of the constituent atoms in a molecule relative to each other. Vibrational energy stretches and compresses a bond, much like a mechanical spring, and this NSF-funded research has shown that it is possible to accelerate the rate of a reaction by depositing energy in a particular bond in a molecule. Even more strikingly, it shows that it is even possible to steer the course of a reaction by preferentially exciting particular vibrations, resulting in selectively breaking one chemical bond over another. This “vibrational-state-controlled” chemistry is one long sought goal in fundamental studies of reactions.

This NSF-supported research previously demonstrated such vibrational state control of chemistry. One of the major outcomes of the current research is the extension of these studies to reactions in solution, rather than in the pristine, low-pressure environments where vibrationally excited molecules react during a single collision. Transferring these studies to solutions required bringing the technology of ultrafast lasers to bear, in order to excite molecules in a time that is shorter that the interval between interactions in solution. These lasers produce pulses that last about 100 fs, a duration that is one-tenth of a millionth of a millionth of a second. Using this technology has allowed the study of exothermic reactions, which do not require added energy, as well as endothermic reactions, where added vibrational energy is essential.

By studying the exothermic reaction of Cl atoms in solution using an ultrafast laser pulse to start the reaction and another infrared pulse to detect the products, these experiments determine the relative rates of reaction of different molecules and the fate of the energy released in solution. The solution reactions resemble those in the gas phase in that energy preferentially appears as vibrational excitation of the products, but the extent of excitation is less in solution, likely because of interactions with the surroundings. Fully understanding the observed trends requires sophisticated theoretical calculations.

By studying the endothermic reaction of Br with different solvent molecules, the experiments provided the first evidence that vibrational excitation of molecules in solution was able to make the reaction occur. Because there is insufficient energy otherwise, the reaction does not occur without vibrational excitation of the reactants. The challenge in these experiments is to find conditions in which the vibrationally excited molecules react before the energy flows out of the initially excited molecule into the surroundings. These results point to a general theme. In many cases the surroundings affect the course of a reaction in solution to a relatively minor degree, showing that ideas developed to understand reactions in gases also inform pictures of reactions in liquids.
